body.p:
My brother in law Rev. A. P. Mendes of
Birmingham calls my attention in a letter received from him
yesterday to the fact that Dr Wise of Cincinnati accuses
him most wrongfully of plagiarism in a sermon called
“The Perpetual Light” preached by Mr. M. in London and
continues “I have addressed myself to Mr Leeser to whom I have
written a letter for publication in the Occident and have also
sent my sermon claimed by this Wise, for publication in
his pages. I do not know whether he will oblige me with the
space solicited as I have not the pleasure to be known to him.
Will you oblige me by using your influence with him to procure
for my request his kind consideration?” At Mr M's expression
“all my influence with you” I could but smile. I regretted
however that though misconception he should have written
to the last person competent to do him a service with you in
the matter. Fortunately for him his case (in my humble,
estimation) is one that recommends itself by its own merits.
Though I believe too much is made of the affair on both sides
yet some texts (and God forbid there should be a monopoly
of Scripture) and even identical ideas do not warrant the
harsh term plagiarism. I have not seen Mr M's sermon
(and therefore my name must not appear in this controversy
as yet,) but (I am pretty sure from my intimate knowledge)
of him his abilities & (principles that he would not stoop

to the plagiarism of which he is accused. Now, my dear Sir, although
I cannot “use any influence with you to procure for M's request
your kind consideration” still I will venture to represent to you
that as Mr Mendes considers himself wrongfully accused
of no trifling thing, and as you have in the pages of the Occident
declared your willingness to give them to any defense of the
Jewish Ministry when wrongfully accused—and as Mr M's
reputation (and perhaps even to some extent his usefulness
may be endangered were the charge of literary theft not
immediately refuted—your own charity shown in cases
somewhat similar will induce you to give Mr M, an
opportunity of being heard in his defence. I do not urge the many
considerations which occur to me & which would have the effect
of entitling your sympathy in his cause for I do not wish nor have
I time to trouble you with a longer letter, but they will very
—much more—readily occur to you.

Will you oblige me with a line at your convenience to
inform me definitely whether you are willing or decline to
with the joint publication of Templo's Grammar Sarah Joseph
told me you had “said something about its being no use to
print the school books but she forgot what you said exactly”
Did your remarks apply to the Grammar as well as to the other books?
I had thought of being able to put the question to you personally
in New York at the dedication of the hospital, but I can't
conveniently go. Trusting you are in good health I am
with Mrs deS' kind regards
